title-group.article-title: Mungo Park's Artificial Skin; Or, the Year the White Man Passed

ref.mixed-citation: Alexander García Düttmann, Between Cultures: Tensions in the Struggle for Recognition, trans. Kenneth B. Woodgate (London, 2000), 11.
Patchen Markell's Bound by Recognition (Princeton, 2003), esp. 39-43;
Paul Ricoeur's The Course of Recognition, trans. David Pellauer (Cambridge, 2005), esp. 1-22
Frantz Fanon, Black Skin, White Masks (New York, 1967) 228, 229.
Fanon writes in his Introduction, "Man is a yes that vibrates to cosmic har- monies" (8).
Colonial Encounters: Europe and the Native Caribbean, 1492-1797 [London, 1986], 12

Homi Bhabha, "Interrogating Identity: Frantz Fanon and the Postcolonial Preroga- tive," The Location of Culture (New York, 1994), 40.
Fanon, 112 and passim.

Mary Louise Pratt gets it wrong when she notes that Park surfaced unexpectedly at Pisania on the coast of West Africa, alone, destitute, and rather the worse for wear" (Imperial Eyes: Travel Writing and Transculturation [New York, 1992], 69; my emphasis).
Mungo Park, Travels in the Interior Districts of Africa, ed. Kate Ferguson Marsters (Durham, 2000), 304.
Srinivas Aravamudan's work on the multivalent status of account(ing) in enlightenment fictions of Africa (Tropicopolitans: Colonialism and Agency, 1688-1804 [Durham, 1999], 71-102).
David Macey, "Fanon, Phenomenology, Race," Philosophies of Race and Ethnicity, ed. Peter Osborne and Stella Sandford (London, 2002), 29-39.
Diana Fuss's "Interior Colonies: Frantz Fanon and the Politics of Identification," Identification Papers (New York, 1995), esp. 141-148,
Pratt, 84.

(Proceedings of the Association for Promoting the Discovery of the Interior Parts of Africa: Volume 1, ed. Robin Hallett [London, 1967], 6-7).
Johannes Fabian, Time and the Other: How Anthropology Makes Its Object (New York, 2002), 31, 117.
Mary Floyd-Wilson's Eng- lish Ethnicity and Race in Early Modern Drama (London, 2003).
Scott J. Juengel's "Countenancing History: Mary Wollstonecraft, Samuel Stanhope Smith, and Enlightenment Racial Science," ELH 68 no. 4 (Winter 2001): 897-927.
Roxann Wheeler, The Complexion of Race: Categories of Difference in Eighteenth-Century British Culture (Philadelphia, 2000);
David Bindman, Ape to Apollo: Aesthetics and the Idea of Race in the Eighteenth Century (Itha- ca, 2002);

Thomas DiPiero, "Missing Links: Whiteness and the Color of Reason in the Eigh- teenth Century," The Eighteenth Century: Theory and Interpretation 40 no. 2 (1999): 155-74, 172, 169.
DiPiero's essay reappears in a longer form in his book-length White Men Aren't (Durham, 2002).

Ashton Nichols, "Mumbo Jumbo: Mungo Park and the Rhetoric of Romantic Africa," Romanticism, Race, and Imperial Culture, 1780-1834, ed. Alan Richardson and Sonia Hofkosh (Bloomington, 1996), 93-113, 107, 112.
Defoe's Captain Singleton (New York, 1990), 119ff.
"Mungo Park in America: Racial Melan- cholia and African Travel," delivered at the 2004 ASECS Conference in Boston.
"[w]hen we arrived at the blacksmith's place of residence, we dismounted and fired our muskets" (120)!
Wordsworth's Essay on Epitaphs in "Autobiog- raphy as De-Facement," The Rhetoric of Romanticism (New York, 1984), 77.
(Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Essay on the Origin of Languages, trans. Victor Gourevitch [New York, 1986], 246-47).
Fanon, who discusses the "hallucinatory whitening" that is a product of one of the central dilemmas of colonial life, "turn white or disappear" (100).
Pratt, 80-81.
Emily A. Haddad, "Body and Belonging(s): Property in the Captivity of Mungo Park," Colonial and Postcolonial Incarceration, ed. Graeme Harper (London, 2001), 124-44.
Nussbaum's recent The Limits of the Human (see note 14)
"white colour ... is considered as a particular mark of favour" (123).
Park fasts during Rhamadan in order to "manifest a respect for their religious opinions," even though "Karfa frankly told me that I was at liberty to pursue my own inclination" (278).

Moorish women in this garb, they "examined my hair and skin with great attention; but affected to consider me as a sort of inferior being to themselves, and would knit their brows, and seem to shudder, when they looked at the whiteness of my skin" (154-55).

Anthony Gerard Barthelemy's useful discussion of the history of the term in his Black Face, Maligned Race: The Representation of Blacks in English Drama from Shakespeare to Southerne (Baton Rouge, 1987), 1-17.
Jack D'Amico, The Moor in English Renaissance Drama (Tampa, 1991),
Nabil Matar, Turks, Moors, and Englishmen in the Age of Discovery (New York, 1999).
Kant's Physical Geography in Emmanuel Chukwudi Eze's Race and the Enlightenment: A Reader (Cambridge, 1997), 58-64.

Park actually meets "a Negro, whose hair and skin were of a dull white colour ... which are called in the Spanish West Indies Albinos, or white Negroes." He concludes that the complexion is diseased, "cadaverous and unsightly" (294).
